case_vignette:
A 42-year-old woman was admitted to the hospital for complications related to type 2 diabetes. Her inpatient team noticed that her right fifth finger was swollen, red, and appeared to have a fissure. The patient stated that although the fissure was not present since birth, her finger has looked this way for “a while” and typically did not bother her. On examination, she had hyperkeratotic plaques on some of her fingers. She denied trauma to the site of injury and her family and travel history were unremarkable. The patient was diagnosed with a type of skin condition called a fissure, which is a crack in the skin that can be painful and bleed. The patient was prescribed a topical cream to help heal the fissure and was advised to keep the area clean and dry. She was also advised to avoid activities that may cause further irritation to the area.
